results.title: A Nous la Liberte = Freedom for Us
results.brief_description:
Two convicts, Louis and Emile, escape from prison, but Emile is recaptured. Louis makes his way into the world and advances from gramophone salesman to owner of a huge, modern gramophone factory. When Emile is released, he joins is old cellmate at the plant. After things go wrong, they take to the road together as tramps. Clair has created a sublime musical comedy satire on the work ethics and the dehumanizing effects of mass-production techniques. The film inspired Chaplin’s ‘Modern times’, in which there are similar sequences on the assembly line. Danger in ‘A nous la liberte’ often comes in the form of prophetic images of militaristic domination: the factory guards wear proto-fascist armbands and uniforms. The film equates authoritarianism with capitalist exploitation of the working class. Emile’s one time fellow prisoner, Louis becomes a wealthy industrialist and builds a factory modelled on the prison from which he once escaped. But Emile is the Dada remedy to Louis’s capitalist order. Everywhere he goes, straight lines collapse in confusion and mass production comes to a standstill.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Producer, Frank Clifford ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Georges Perinal ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Lazare Meerson.
Cast: Raymond Cordy, Henri Marchand, Rolla France, Paul Olivier, Jacques Shelly, Andre Michaud.

results.title: The Au Harem D'archimede = Tea in the harem
results.brief_description:
“The narrative centers on the adventures of a couple of eighteen-year-olds, Madjid, a Beur and Pat, his illiterate French friend. However, the loose episodic structure of the narrative, covering a week or so in the lives of people living on the ironically named Flowers Estate, allows other stories to be intercalated, particularly that of Josette, a single mother who loses her job and is driven to attempt suicide, and Malika, Madjid’s mother, who not only holds her own family together, but also provides support for other women on the estate who are unable to cope. The film is primarily interested in exploring Madjid’s conflicts of identity, torn between the (unrealistic) expectations his mother has of him as an Algerian and his experiences on the streets of Paris with Pat.” Reference: Carrie Tarr. Questions of identity in Beur cinema: from ‘Tea in the Harem’ to ‘Cheb’. Screen 34:4 (Winter 1993).Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1984.

Credits: Producer, Michele Ray-Gavras ; director, Mehdi Charef ; writer, Mehdi Charef ; photography, Dominique Chapuis ; music, Karim Kacel
Cast: Kader Boukhanef, Remi Martin, Laure Duthilleul, Saida Bekkouche, Nicole Hiss.

results.title: Le Voleur de Crimes = the Crime Thief
results.brief_description:
An unhappily married man with two children watches a beautiful woman kill herself when she ties herself inside a car and drives off a cliff. Jean tries to save the woman but it is too late. After hanging out with his bohemian friends, he writes a letter to the local newspaper saying that he killed the woman. Jean is galvanized by the sensationalism of the headlines and becomes intoxicated with thoughts of murder. He does away with the pretty model and girlfriend of his painter friend in a similar manner. Soon the painter grows suspicious of Jean and believes he is the one who has sent the letters to the paper telling the story of a little man who gains self importance by murder.

Credits: Producer, Alain Queffelean ; director, Nadine Trintignant ; writer, Nadine Trintignant ; photography, Pierre Villemin ; music, Jack Arel ; assistant director, Daniel Vigne.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant ; Robert Hossein, Florinda Bolkan, Serge Marquand, Bernadette Lafont, Tanya Lopert, Georgia Moll, Karen Blanguernon, Francis Girod.

results.title: Le Cave Se Rebiffe = the Counterfeiters
results.brief_description:
A small-time crook, together with a couple of friends, plans a forgery operation using the skills of Robert, an engraver and the husband of his mistress. A professional mastermind is persuaded out of retirement to run the racket, and he and Robert double-cross the others to make off with the loot. This film gave an opportunity to Michel Audiard and Albert Simonin to write finely chiselled dialogues, filled with ‘argot’ and unforgettable one-liners

Credits: Producer, Jacques Bar ; director, Gilles Grangier ; writers, Albert Simonin, Michel Audiard, Gilles Grangier ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Francis Lemarque, Michel Legrand ; art direction, Jacques Colombier.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Maurice Biraud, Martine Carol, Bernard Blier, Francoise Rosay, Ginette Leclerc, Robert Dalban, Franck Willard, Antoine Balpetre, Albert Dinan.

results.title: La Longue Marche = the Long March (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Spring 1944. Docteur Chevalier is running a practice in the Cevennes. Having been himself involved in the war and the subsequent defeat in 1940, he is neither hostile nor sympathetic to the Resistance movement that holds the neighbouring mountains. One night he is taken at gun point to take care of a wounded Resistance fighter. The group is commanded by Carnot who also wages a war of his own against one of his men, de Brunerolles. Soon after, the Nazis surround the stronghold. Under the orders of De Brunerolles, the group has to flee and start a long march across the Cevennes mountains.

Credits: Director, Alexandre Astruc ; writers, Alexandre Astruc, Jean-Charles Tacchella, Jacques-Laurent Bost ; photography, Jean-Jacques Rochut ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Robert Hossein, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Maurice Ronet, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Paul Frankeur, Robert Dalban, Berthe Granval.

results.title: Gervaise
results.brief_description:
Abandonned by her lover shortly after her arrival in Paris, Gervaise brings up her two children while working as a laundress. She marries Copeau, a carpenter and they have a daughter Nana. Gervaise opens her own laundry business and the family prospers and thrives. Copeau has an accident and becomes handicapped. Dejected, he finds solace in alcohol and soons drags Gervaise in a downward spiral of poverty and alcoholism. To recreate the atmosphere of the popular areas of 19th century Paris, Rene Clement drew inspiration from photographs by famous pioneer photographer Nadar. Awards: Venice Film Festival 1956 Volpi Cup for Best Actress: Maria Schell ; British Academy Awards 1956 Best Foreign Actor: Francois Perier.

Credits: Producer, Annie Dorfmann ; director, Rene Clement ; writers, Jean Aurenche, Pierre Bost ; photography, Robert Juillard ; music, Georges Auric ; songs, Raymond Queneau ; costumes, Mayo.
Cast: Maria Schell, Francois Perier, Armand Mestral, Suzy Delair, Florelle, Jany Holt, Micheline Luccioni.

results.title: Souvenirs, Souvenirs = Memories, Memories
results.brief_description:
Paris, 1962. Rego Boccara is back from a tour of duty in Algeria and attempts to revive his singing career. His agent, Nadia, must help him fight the animosity of Firmani, an influent music-hall owner, who has vowed never to allow Rego back on stage. Meanwhile, Antoine, Rego’s younger brother, is marking time at the local high school, until the day he meets the new music teacher. This ‘coming of age’ drama is a faithful portraiture of France and its youth culture in the early 1960s. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1985: Best Promising Young Actor for Pierre-Loup Rajot.

Credits: Producer, Ariel Zeitoun ; director, Ariel Zeitoun ; writer, Daniel Saint-Hamont, Ariel Zeitoun ; photography, Bruno de Keyzer ; music, Cyril Assous, Jean-Paul Dreau ; assistant director, Regis Wargnier.
Cast: Christophe Malavoy, Pierre-Loup Rajot, Claude Brasseur, Annie Girardot, Marlene Jobert, Philippe Noiret, Jean Benguigui.

results.title: Defense de Savoir = Forbidden to Know
results.brief_description:
Maitre Laube is a humble lawyer who is called on to the defense of Simone, a prostitute accused of murdering her lover. The lover was actually killed during a holdup, and was a member of a gang which did bullying favors for local politicians. Faced with Simone’s refusal to cooperate, Laube is left alone to unravel a much more complicated plot than he anticipated.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Nadine Marquand Trintignant ; writers, Alain Corneau, Nadine Trintignant ; photography, William Lubtchansky ; music, Bruno Nicolai.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Michel Bouquet, Bernadette Lafont, Juliet Berto, Claude Pieplu, Charles Denner, Barbara Laage, Serge Marquand, Marie Trintignant.

results.title: Tout L'or du Monde = All the Gold in the World
results.brief_description:
Dumont, an obstinate peasant, his son and cousin refuse to sell their land with its health-giving water spring to property developers anxious to turn the place into a fashionable spa. This late comedy of Rene Clair makes fun of all the trappings of modernity. Bourvil has a lot of fun playing all the members of the uncompromising Dumont family.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Plante ; director, Rene Clair ; writers, Rene Clair, Jean Marsan, Jacques Remy ; photography, Pierre Petit ; music, Georges van Parys.
Cast: Annie Fratellini, Bourvil, Colette Castel, Philippe Noiret, Francoise Dorleac, Alfred Adam.

results.title: A Bout de Souffle = Breathless
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Michel, on the run after shooting a policeman, is betrayed by his girlfriend, Patricia, an expatriate American. The plot is drawn from the ‘B’ crime thriller (the film is dedicated to Monogram Pictures, Hollywood’s all-B movie studio) and Godard pays homage to Hollywood’s action genres but his free approach to narrative and stylistics made this the most original and influential of the early New Wave films. The theme of the limits of personal freedom on the boundary between anarchism and nihilism emerges almost casually. The sense of dislocation is most obvious in Godard’s use of the jump cut, a device which he rarely, if ever, used again although he retained the effect. A more accurate translation of the title is ‘out of breath’ rather than the more romantic ‘breathless’.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Martial Solal.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Seberg, Jean-Pierre Melville, Roger Hanin, Daniel Boulanger, Richard Balducci.

A more accurate translation of the title is ‘out of breath’ rather than the more romantic ‘breathless’.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Martial Solal.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Seberg, Jean-Pierre Melville, Roger Hanin, Daniel Boulanger, Richard Balducci.
